Project Description  The Project involves improving, upgrading, and expanding urban 
infrastructure facilities and basic urban services (water supply, 
urban  roads,  urban  drainage  and  sewerage,  solid  waste 
management,  and  small-scale  community  infrastructure  [(basic 
health clinic, etc.)] in at least 68 local authorities (LAs). Through 
technical assistance from provincial councils, LAs will apply for 
finance from the Local Loans and Development Fund (LLDF). The 
Project  also  involves  institutional  strengthening  and  capacity 
building  of  state,  provincial,  and  local  agencies  in  urban 
management  and  urban  service  provision,  as  well  as  poverty 
reduction initiatives developed through stakeholder participation.     
   
Rationale  The huge influx of mostly poor migrants into cities and towns has 
overwhelmed infrastructure systems originally designed for much 
smaller populations. With limited infrastructure and services, the 
old  and  new  urban  centers  are  not  capable  of  adequately 
supporting the increasing economic productivity of households. 
The urban poor suffer disproportionately from bad environmental 
sanitation, resulting in illness caused by water- and vector-borne 
disease. Urban service deficiencies include deteriorated roads, 
inadequate  supplies  of  potable  water,  and  poor  drainage  and 
domestic sanitation. The vast majority of urban residents still rely 
on  septic  tanks  or  have  no  sanitation  facilities;  only  23%  of 
households have sewerage connections. Uncontrolled dumping 
and low collection levels of solid waste add to these problems.       
   
Impact and Outcome  The expected impact of the Project is increased growth potential 
of  and  reduced  poverty  in  urban  centers  of  Sri  Lanka.  The 
expected outcome is improved quality of life for urban residents, 
including the poor and the disadvantaged, and enhanced urban 
productivity in at least 68 urban towns. 
 
Cost Estimates  The estimated project cost is $66.7 million equivalent, comprising 
foreign exchange costs of $21.1 million and local currency costs 
equivalent to $45.6 million, including taxes and duties of $7.7 
million.

Local  procurement  will  be  the  preferred  mode  for  all  project 
activities. None of the Project’s civil works contracts are expected 
to exceed $500,000 in cost. Local competitive bidding procedures 
acceptable to ADB will be followed with bidding periods of at least 
21  days.  Equipment  and  materials  will  be  procured  under 
international competitive bidding where the estimated cost is more

Project Benefits and  The main benefits of the Project will be (i) an increasingly more 
Beneficiaries  capable and accountable local government governance system; 
(ii) a foundation for sustainable and reliable urban services; and 
(iii) improved economic and social conditions in the participating 
LAs from investments in roads, drainage, community water, solid 
waste management, and other basic urban facilities and services 
(including sanitation).  
 
The  Project  will  benefit  several  groups.  Households  and 
businesses will benefit from a more accountable, responsive, and 
empowered  local  government,  as  well  as  directly  from 
improvements  in  urban  services  and  investments,  and  in  the

urban environment. Elected LA governments will gain from having 
their legitimacy enhanced, as a result of their improved ability to 
provide  services,  and  from  greater  financial  and  managerial 
autonomy.  The  urban  poor  will  obtain  health  and  productivity 
benefits  from  investments  in  environmental  infrastructure 
(drainage, community water, solid waste management, etc.), as 
they suffer disproportionately from the ill effects of the lack of such 
services. Finally, predominantly local private contractors and their 
workers, as well as suppliers, will benefit from the flow of more 
than  $42.6  million  in  contracts  for  municipal  civil  works  and 
equipment over the 6 years of the Project. About 4 million people, 
the population of at least 68 new municipalities, will benefit from  
the capacity-building component.    
 
Risks and Assumptions  Given the innovative design adopted in the Project, where LAs will 
be  responsible  for  identifying  and  preparing  Subprojects  and 
where the strengthened LLDF will appraise credit worthiness of 
LAs  and  viability  of  Subprojects,  inherent  risks  need  to  be 
monitored carefully throughout project implementation. At present, 
LAs lack experience to prepare Subproject proposals for external 
funding.  Similarly,  LLDF's  role  as  a  fully  functioning  financial 
intermediary  is  new;  in  the  past  it  served  mainly  as  a  debt 
collector for MPCLG. Under the Project, however, the roles and 
functions of LAs and LLDF are expected to go through substantial 
change.  LAs  need  to  develop  a  sense  of  ownership  for  the 
Subprojects they will develop. LLDF will have to be reborn as a 
competent financial intermediary to efficiently channel the financial 
resources made  available  under  the  Project  to  LAs.  Foreseen 
risks include (i) lack of awareness and suitably qualified personnel 
in LAs and the CLG office to assume the new responsibilities; (ii) 
insufficient  support  from  policymakers  for  the  envisaged 
transformation of LAs and LLDF; (iii) poor performance of LAs in 
repaying the LLDF loans, which may trigger the use of guarantees 
by provincial councils, and (iv) political interference in Subproject 
selection. These risks are mitigated to the greatest extent possible 
by (i) ensuring LLDF’s readiness prior to subloan disbursement 
under component B through a tailored institutional strengthening 
program  for  LLDF;  (ii)  clearly  defined  eligibility  conditions  and 
Subproject  approval  criteria;  (iii)  carefully  designed  awareness 
and capacity-building programs for LAs and provincial councils; 
and  (iv)  increased  supervision,  through  a  supporting  technical 
assistance project and regular loan review missions. 
 
Subproject selection will prioritize rehabilitation of existing basic 
urban  infrastructure  over  new  construction  involving  small-  to 
medium-scale  civil  and  building  works  at  sites  previously  or 
currently used for the same or similar purposes. The Subproject 
selection criteria rules out Subprojects classified as environment 
safeguard  category  “A”  or  “B  sensitive.”  The  Project  is  not 
expected to result in significant land acquisition and resettlement, 
or to have adverse impact on indigenous people.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the Local Government Infrastructure 
Improvement Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  Sri Lanka has a relatively high population density of 295 people per square kilometer 
(km2), greater than that of the Philippines or Viet Nam. The country’s high population density is 
a major factor in the Government’s economic development strategy, industrialization policy, and 
support of medium- and small-sized towns. The current urban population is about 5 million; 1.5 
million reside in Colombo. The prolonged conflict and low productivity in rural areas have had a 
severe impact on urban centers. Many rural people fled to urban areas, which in some cases 
have grown by 300% during the past two decades. Urban migration has converted some small 
rural towns to urban centers. On average, the urban population is growing nearly twice as fast 
as the rural population. The urban population now represents about 27% of the national total 
and is still growing rapidly, at nearly 6% per year compared with a total national population 
growth rate of around 1%. The degree of urbanization is projected to reach 45% by 2015.  
 
3.  Condition of Urban Areas. With limited infrastructure and services, the old and new 
urban centers are not capable of adequately supporting the increasing economic productivity of 
households. Living conditions in urban centers are poor for most residents. The urban poor 
suffer disproportionately from poor environmental sanitation resulting in illness caused by water- 
and vector-borne disease. Urban service deficiencies include deteriorated roads, inadequate 
supplies of potable water, and poor drainage and domestic sanitation. Poverty incidence in 
urban areas stood at 8% in 2002. The vast majority of urban residents still rely on septic tanks 
or have no sanitation facilities; only 23% of households have sewerage connections; and of the 
total 58,350 km of local authority (LA) roads, 25-40% are in very poor condition and may not 
meet national standards. Uncontrolled dumping and low collection levels of solid waste add to 
these problems.  
 
4.  Inadequate Local Infrastructure Services. The prolonged political situation, financial 
constraints, and 20 years of civil strife have impeded LA provision of essential public services. 
The difficult conditions have also hampered economic growth and poverty reduction. Major 
urban deficiencies include (i) most towns have intermittent piped water supply services provided 
by the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB); (ii) areas without piped waste 
schemes are serviced by tubewells; many are run privately or through community schemes and 
thus have different tariffs; (iii) most tertiary roads are in a complete state of disrepair; (iv) 
drainage problems are fairly widespread; encroachment into low-lying paddy fields and river 
basins is rampant; (v) very few LAs have a systemized waste management system; waste 
collection is generally carried out manually, is not separated, and is dumped on public roads 
due to lack of proper collection space; (vi) only Colombo has a piped sewerage system; and (vii) 
primary LA health care facilities are limited due to weak capacity and financial resources.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
5.  Creation of Provincial Councils. In Sri Lanka, devolution was perceived as an exit 
strategy from civil conflict in the north and the east. In 1987 the Government took a major 
initiative for decentralization through the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution, which led to

2 
the  creation  of  an  additional  tier  of  government,  the  provincial  councils,1  in  1988.  The 
amendment carved out a provincial sphere of governance, specifying an area of legislative, 
executive,  and  financial  competence  to  be  exercised  by  the  councils.  Article  154  in  the 
Constitution contains three lists of competencies: the responsibilities of the center (Reserved 
List), the provinces (Provincial List), and an area of overlapping responsibilities (Concurrent 
List). Through this process, institutions of local self-government that had operated under a 
centralized  system  became  a  devolved  subject  of  the  provincial  council.  The  operational 
aspects, such as LA operation and administration, were assigned to the provinces. However, 
the central Government retains powers over LAs, providing technical support for planning, 
appraisal, procurement, and management.  
 
6.  Three  Types  of  Local  Authorities.  Sri  Lanka  has  three  types  of  LAs  under  the 
provincial councils: (i) municipal councils constituted in cities and large towns, (ii) urban councils 
for less urbanized areas, and (iii) pradeshiya sabhas created in periurban and rural areas. All 
three  have  separate  enabling  laws  providing  the  legal  and  policy  environment  for  local 
government institutions to operate and function. The three types of LAs are created, regulated, 
and operated by three different ordinances.  
 
7.  Responsibility of Local Authorities. LAs, being created by Parliament, are subject to 
general supervision and control by the Government through the Ministry of Provincial Councils 
and Local Government (MPCLG). Following the devolution system, the LAs are placed under 
the provincial councils. In the present system, provincial councils cannot reduce the existing 
powers of LAs, and if necessary, LAs can be vested with additional powers. Numerous laws 
confer powers to LAs on various aspects of local administration, such as the Local Government 
Service Ordinance and the Urban Development Authority Act. The main powers and functions of 
LAs are described in their respective acts and ordinances. For example, they have the power to 
acquire land, enter into contracts, raise funds, purchase material and equipment, and employ 
staff. But their main responsibility is to provide conveniences and well-being to the community. 
Consequently, they are responsible for providing physical infrastructure such as roads, drains, 
parks, libraries, and housing; and for promoting public health. Hence, this Project fits with the 
decentralized system currently in place, and aims to strengthen LA powers to improve the 
provision of basic infrastructure services in their respective areas.2 
 
8.  Physical  Planning  and  Legal  Framework.  Seven  laws3  govern  the  existing  legal 
framework of urban planning and land management. Urban planning involves, among others, 
the Urban Development Authority operating in UDA “declared” areas, and Board of Investment 
with overriding powers for board-approved projects and areas.4 NWSDB is the main agency 
responsible for water supply and manages over 75% of piped water schemes, especially areas 
dependent on NWSDB water sources. LAs operate and maintain the remaining schemes, often 
receiving bulk treated water from NWSDB. LAs are responsible for communal water supply 
(e.g., tubewells); in some cases, to achieve full cost recovery, the water tariffs are higher than 
the NWSDB national tariff.

9.  Limited Local Resource Mobilization and Local Loans and Development Fund. LA 
sources of revenue, especially for recurrent expenditure, are low. In 2003, about 36% of the 
total recurrent revenue for municipal councils was provided as a government grant, and about 
42% in the case of urban councils and pradeshiya sabhas.5 Sources of revenue, along with 
shared  taxes  and  grants,  are  inadequate  to  meet  the  needs  of  basic  urban  infrastructure 
services. The main revenue sources include the stamp duty levied on property and other 
transactions, and the assessment tax levied on the deemed value of property and rents. The 
acreage tax levied by the pradeshiya sabhas is gradually decreasing, due to large tracts of land 
being converted to housing use. Recurrent expenditures are increasing and now represent an 
average of 70% of total expenditures. Of these, over 40% are consumed by personnel costs. 
Consequently, spending on maintaining LA assets is a low proportion of total expenditure, and 
LAs are unable to afford new investment in basic urban services. Although provincial councils 
have  extensive  revenue  authorities,  in  reality,  revenues  available  to  them  are  limited.  On 
average, provincial councils’ own-source revenues account for only 10% of their expenditures. 
Recurrent expenditure is financed by own recurrent revenues and from a revenue grant (block 
grant) funded by the central Government. The Local Loans and Development Fund (LLDF) was 
created in 1916 to improve access to financing for local capitalized repairs. LLDF is a statutory 
body  operating  under  MPCLG  (Appendix  2).  Its  main  functions  include  granting  and 
administering loans for investment in LA infrastructure development and revenue-generating 
projects. Except for MPCLG supervision and control, LLDF is not under any control or subject to 
regulations of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka.6  
 
10.  Institutional  and  Staff  Capacity.  Another  factor  fundamental  to  sustainable  urban 
development is the LA institutional framework and staff capacity. LAs should be fully responsible 
and accountable for providing local services. Although Sri Lanka has a large bureaucracy, the 
level and quality of local staff is generally not high. In 2004, almost 1 million public servants 
were employed by all levels of government; 63% were employed by the central Government, 
32% by provincial councils, and 5% by LAs.7 LAs need to improve their human resource 
capabilities, particularly in financial management and technical skills to manage infrastructure 
under its control. Except for Colombo and other larger municipal councils, LAs have few senior 
engineers, planners, or financial specialists, although the larger LAs do have midlevel technical 
personnel. The Project will provide technical consultants to fill in the gaps and help LAs develop 
solid Subprojects proposals. During the Project, the technical consultants’ input will be gradually 
reduced; LA technical staff are expected to assume responsibility for preparing Subproject 
proposals.      
 
11.  External Assistance and Lessons Learned. Several externally funded projects in the 
area of urban infrastructure have been implemented during the past decade (Appendix 3). The 
Sustainable Cities Programme of the United Nations-Habitat and United Nations Development 
Programme evolved into the Urban Governance Support Programme (2004–2005). It provided 
capacity-building support to the Urban Development Authority and some selected municipalities. 
Pilot projects in solid waste management have produced tangible progress in the areas of 
garbage collection and communal participation, and instilled confidence in LA staff and local 
communities concerned. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been the major development 
partner  in  the  urban  sector  in  recent  years.  ADB’s  Urban  Development  and  Low-Income

12.  Project  Development  Process.  A  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA) 
prepared the proposed Project. A series of consultations were held with MPCLG, all eight 
participating  provincial  councils,  and  participating  LAs.  Project  design  incorporates  lessons 
learned (para. 11): setting out clear plans for institutional strengthening and implementation of 
the delivery of basic urban infrastructure that local populations actually demand and are willing 
to maintain. The Project is in line with the Government’s development priorities and ADB’s 
country strategy and program (2004–2008) to improve infrastructure and services provision, 
particularly water supply and sanitation. These constitute a basic human right; representing a 
crucial  factor  in  preventing  illness  and  raising  universal  health  status.  Following  the 
stakeholders’ discussion, wherein a detailed questionnaire was circulated to all LAs. Responses 
were received from 189 LAs representing nearly two thirds of the eligible LAs. Based on the 
scores from the questionnaire and a decision by the second Steering Committee meeting, 68 
priority  LAs  were  selected  (Appendix  4).  Local  government  capacity  building is  needed  to 
prioritize and commit investment. The most critical strategic choice made by the project design 
is to place modest capital directly in the hands of the LAs and to allow them to decide on the 
subsectors and support them to enhance their powers to collect revenues, which falls under 
their existing rights.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The expected impact of the Project is increased growth potential of and reduced poverty 
in the selected LAs of Sri Lanka. The expected outcome is improved urban environments, long-
term improvement of the economy, and improved living conditions for the LA population outside 
Colombo. The Project will (i) improve urban management, planning, and financing capacity of 
the sector institutions, especially LAs, to ensure sustainable provision of urban infrastructure 
and services; (ii) enhance urban livelihoods; and (iii) increase Government and LA staff capacity 
for administering urban infrastructure supply and maintenance works. 
 
B.  Outputs 
 
14.  The Project will comprise three components. Component A: provincial/municipal/urban 
management improvement, includes three key areas: (i) infrastructure development planning 
and financial management support to LAs (Financial and Local Improvement Plans), (ii) Project 
Development Assistance (PDA) support to provincial councils, and (iii) strengthening of LLDF 
fund management. Component B: basic local government infrastructure and services delivery 
will improve LA infrastructure and services, namely (i) community water supply; (ii) roads; (iii) 
drainage and community sewerage; (iv) solid waste management; and (v) basic health clinics,

C.  Special Features 
 
15.  LA Demand-Based Project. The Project represents a shift in ADB’s approach from 
supply-driven central Government-led investment to a more decentralized approach of providing 
LAs with the decision-making role. LAs will identify, design, and apply for Subproject finance to 
LLDF.  Subprojects  are  not  predefined  at  the  feasibility  study  stage.  The  aim  is  for  LAs 
themselves to plan the improvement of their basic infrastructure and living conditions (Appendix 
5 provides the urban sector analysis). The approach shift stems from lessons learned from ADB 
and other foreign-aided projects, with the Government’s decentralization initiatives. Investment 
programs for LA infrastructure should be implemented by LAs in the interest of building capacity 
through learning by doing and promoting sustainable investment. Many provincial councils and 
LAs stated during the project preparatory TA that they were not involved in the design for 
buildings and facilities provided through previous projects, because they were prioritized by the 
central  agency  from  Colombo.  When  a  typical  externally  financed  project  ends,  the 
infrastructure will often deteriorate, because no budget is set aside at the LA, and the LA has no 
keen interest in maintaining it, because those facilities were not local top priorities. In this 
Project, provincial councils and LAs will have a say in the decision making on Subproject 
identification, formulation, and implementation. Provincial councils will have the responsibility of 
recovering loans and interests due from their LAs and ensure repayment. Provincial councils will 
have authority to recover/intercept funds due to any defaulting LA for repayment of loans under 
the Project. 
 
16.  LA Infrastructure Financed by LLDF and Project Development Assistance. LLDF 
will provide credit, which is mixture of grant and loan. The Government is strongly committed to 
LLDF as the primary vehicle for financing local infrastructure, and this Project will support 
MPCLG’s efforts to strengthen LLDF to fulfill its mandate. Preliminarily financial management 
assessment and due diligence were conducted.10 Further LLDF capacity building (including a 
business  plan  and  finance  operational  guidelines),  necessary  guidelines,  comprehensive 
financial due diligence reports, and relevant legal documents will be prepared in the early stage 
of the Project and separate TA.11 PDA will be provided to the target 68 LAs of all 8 provinces.12 
The consultative approach for Subproject design is the key principle for designing the Project, 
as  well  as  a  bottom-up  approach  to  strengthen  LAs  to  plan,  develop,  and  finance  urban 
infrastructure. This will lead to the improvement of local government performance to their local 
constituencies.

c.  Local Authority Drainage and Communal Sewerage 
 
26.  Drainage  problems  are  fairly  widespread.  With  the  increase  in  urbanization  more

peak rate of runoff. Older drains and culverts are inadequate and need to be expanded and

report problems. Equipment needs are frequently cited. Improved urban planning is fundamental 
to solving drainage and flood control problems, with work including (i) elimination of blockages, 
obstructions, and encroachments on existing drainage paths; (ii) construction of new drains to

may opt for repair and improvement of existing sanitation systems. Most LAs rely on septic 
tanks and pit latrines because construction of proper sanitation facilities is difficult due to high

awareness of the importance of a clean and pleasant environment for sound livelihood, tourism,

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Expected Project Benefits and Impacts 
 
52.   The  main  benefits  of  the  Project  will  be  (i)  an  increasingly  more  capable  and 
accountable local government governance system; (ii) a foundation for sustainable and reliable 
urban  services  through  more  effective  LA  management  and  finance;  and  (iii)  improved 
economic and social conditions in the participating LAs from investments in roads, drainage, 
community water, solid waste management, and other small-scale community facilities. 
 
53.  The Project will benefit several groups. Households and businesses in LAs will benefit 
from a more accountable, responsive, and empowered local government, as well as directly 
from improvements in urban services and investments, and in the urban environment. Elected 
LA governments will gain from enhancement of their legitimacy, as a result of improved ability to 
provide services and from greater financial and managerial autonomy. The urban poor will 
obtain health and productivity benefits from the investments in environmental infrastructure, as 
they  suffer  disproportionately  from  the  ill  effects  of  the  lack  of  such  services.  Finally, 
predominantly local private contractors and their workers, as well as suppliers, will benefit from 
the flow of more than $42 million in contracts for municipal civil works and equipment over the 6 
years of the Project. At least 4 million people, the total population of at least 68 municipalities, 
will benefit from changes in the legal and institutional framework and from the capacity-building 
component. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10.  
 
54.  Resettlement and Indigenous Peoples. The Project provides direct social benefits 
through increased access to basic urban infrastructure and services, and enhances the potential 
for investments and economic growth in poor areas. The Project is not expected to result in 
significant  land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  The  Subproject  selection  criteria  ensure  that 
Subprojects resulting in significant resettlement will not be part of the Project. Further, the 
Project will prioritize rehabilitation of existing basic urban infrastructure over new construction.

17
Where land acquisition is required, the use of Government land will be preferred, avoiding 
private  land  in  Subproject  siting  and  alignment.  If  any  land  acquisition  and  involuntary 
resettlement  will  be  required  in  Subprojects,  the  Government  and  LLDF  will  follow  the 
resettlement framework. The Project will monitor the LA decision-making process to ensure that 
decisions  are  reached  in  a  participatory  manner,  and  no  vulnerable  groups  are  adversely 
impacted by Subprojects. Project design includes an indigenous peoples framework to ensure 
project benefits are equally shared, should a Subproject have impacts on indigenous peoples. 
 
55.  Environment. The Project is classified as “FI,” in accordance with ADB’s Environment 
Policy (2002). An environmental assessment of financial intermediation loans was prepared. 
Subprojects will be designed to maximize environmental benefits including improved drinking 
water quality through improvements in water supply; reduced depletion of water resources by 
improving  the  management  of  existing  water  supply  schemes;  improved  surface  and 
groundwater quality, and solid waste management; reduced flooding through drainage; reduced 
air pollution from improving roads; and improved health and increased social benefits from 
developing  institutional  infrastructure  including  health,  education,  community  parks,  and 
administrative facilities.   
 
56.  Subproject selection will prioritize rehabilitation of existing basic urban infrastructure over 
new construction involving small- to medium-size civil and building works at sites previously or 
currently used for the same or similar purposes.32 The Subproject selection criteria rules out 
Subprojects that would be classified as category “A” or “B sensitive” in accordance with ADB’s 
Environment  Policy.  During  project  preparation,  an  initial  environmental  examination  was 
conducted.  Subprojects  will  not  generate  significant  adverse  environmental  impacts.  Most 
potential adverse environmental impacts are temporary and localized, and can be addressed 
through Subproject design and mitigation measures incorporated in contractors’ contracts. To 
ensure  compliance  with  the  Government  and  ADB’s  environmental  guidelines  and 
requirements,  environmental  assessment  and  review  procedures  were  prepared  to  guide 
Subproject implementation and are in the environmental assessment of financial intermediation. 
 
57.  Sustainability.  Initial  financial  projections  and  a  financial  management  assessment 
were prepared for LLDF in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Financial Governance and 
Management of Investment Projects Financed by ADB to assess the viability and sustainability 
of the Project. This preliminary financial due diligence indicates that LLDF will be financially self-
sufficient, and upon completion of capacity development activities under component A, will have 
sufficient  financial  management  capacity.  An  initial  affordability  assessment  of  two  sample 
communities indicates sufficient demand to justify the size of component B, and that LAs will 
have  the  capacity  to  absorb  debt  service  and  recurrent  cost  obligations.  The  Project  is 
considered both financially viable and sustainable. 
 
B.  Major Risks 
 
58.  Given the innovative design adopted in the Project, where LAs will be responsible for 
identifying  and  preparing  Subprojects  and  where  the  strengthened  LLDF  will  appraise 
creditworthiness  of  LAs  and  viability  of  Subprojects,  inherent  risks  need  to  be  monitored 
carefully  throughout  project  implementation.  At  present,  LAs  lack  experience  to  prepare 
Subproject proposals for external funding. Similarity, LLDF's role as a fully functioning financial 
intermediary is new; it served mainly as a debt collector for MPCLG in the past. Under the 
Project,  however,  the  roles  and  functions  of  LAs  and  LLDF  are  expected  to  change 
substantially. LAs need to develop a sense of ownership for the Subprojects they will develop. 
LLDF will have to become a competent financial intermediary to efficiently channel the financial

A.  Legal Organization Status and Mandate 
 
1.  The Local Loans and Development Fund (LLDF) is a statutory body operating under the 
Ministry of Provincial Councils and Local Government (MPCLG). Created under the Local Loans 
and Development Ordinance No.22 of 1916, which has been amended from time to time, the 
main functions of LLDF include granting and administering loans for investment in infrastructure 
development  and  revenue-generating  projects  of  local  authorities  (LAs).  LLDF  is  still  not 
autonomous; it is still under the general supervision of MPCLG (para. 6). Since it does not 
accept deposits from the general public, it is not under any control or subject to regulation of the 
Central Bank of Sri Lanka. 
 
1.  Status and Mandated Functions  
 
2.  The prime objective of LLDF is to meet the capital investment needs of the LAs through 
lending. It advances loans to LAs at a market-based rate of interest, as well as to any person or 
body for any purpose of public utility. LLDF loans are subject to limits of borrowing powers of the 
LA as prescribed in their governing law/ordinance.  
 
3.  In  its  early  stages  (1930–1950),  LLDF  provided  loan  facilities  to  state  officers  and 
cooperative  societies.  But  after  1950,  its  activities  were  limited  to  LAs.  Until  1984,  the 
Department of Local Government managed LLDF. One of the highlights of this period was the 
inability of LLDF to fully utilize treasury allocations1. In 1985, LLDF was assigned to the Urban 
Planning  Unit  under  the  Municipal  Management  Project.  During  this  period  LLDF  was 
recognized by  LAs  as  a  nodal  funding  agency.  Since  UPU  was  dissolved  in  1995,  LLDF 
recruited permanent staff and has since managed on its own. For the first 5 years, i.e., until 
2000 the Treasury made all salary reimbursements. Since then, LLDF has not relied on the 
Treasury for recurrent expenditures. During 2003, LLDF management transferred to MPCLG. 
 
4.  LLDF is primarily capitalized through sums appropriated by the central Government 
(General Treasury through MPCLG), and recovery of repayment of its loans. The law also 
provides  for  sourcing  of  loans  by  LLDF  from  the  consolidated  fund,  commercial  banks, 
government-sponsored lending institutions, and loans from LAs themselves. Presently, LLDF 
receives  funds  from  the  Treasury  in  the  form  of  loan  at  a  concessionary  rate  of  interest 
repayable to the Treasury in 25 years. As on 31 December 2004, the total amount of loans 
granted to LAs was SLRs377 million. LLDF keeps a margin on interest to cover its overheads, 
thus causing no burden to the Treasury with regard to LLDF management.  
 
5.  LLDF could set up a trust fund; contribute to the central revenue stream when directed 
by the minister in charge; and pay all expenses incurred for LLDF administration and all sums 
that from time-to-time may be payable, by way of principal or interest, on sums lent to the 
commissioners by LLDF.  
 
2.  Organization Structure and Functional Staffing  
 
6.  A board of commissioners consisting of 13 members manages the LLDF. Chaired by the 
MPCLG secretary, the board includes all commissioners of local government (CLGs), public 
officers nominated by the minister in charge of irrigation, power, highways, and finance. The 
minister with the local government portfolio appoints all commissioners. The commissioners 
constitute  the  body  corporate.  The  chief  executive  officer  looks  after  the  day-to-day

required for stringent project appraisal, loan documentation, and monitoring and loan recovery 
will be set up. In addition, a strategy for engagement with provincial councils and LAs, and legal 
recourse for debt recovery under project loans will be developed. The second task will include 
analyzing the existing loan portfolio and identifying priority sectors. As a part of the evaluation of

will be identified and made available to provide support for implementing various components of 
the business plan. Training needs assessment of the existing staff vis-à-vis the requirements of 
the business plan will also be undertaken to upgrade the skills of existing staff. Marketing of 
LLDF will be an important component; workshops and other awareness-building exercises will 
be conducted in an effort to build demand and the loan application pipeline. Since subproject 
funding will have been initiated, reforms in treasury management especially for unlent funds will

D.  LA Options to Repay an LLDF Loan 
 
30.   LAs undertake a number of functions essential for the welfare of the society. As part of 
their jurisdictional powers, LAs are authorized to collect revenues against some of the services 
provided by them in form of user charges (direct services), tax, fines, cesses, etc. Although cost 
recovery by LAs is not predominant, it has the potential to become a major source of own 
revenue. Unfortunately, most LAs are already hard pressed to provide even the minimum level 
of basic services due to resource and institutional constraints. LAs have the power to impose 
the following taxes within their jurisdiction:   
 
(i)  LA assessment rate (similar to property tax), 
(ii)  entertainment tax, 
(iii)  tax on animals and vehicles, 
(iv)  licence fees (stamp duties), 
(v)  rents, and  
(vi)  user charges (service tax).

Appendix 2  33
 
These taxes are critical and can provide buoyancy to the overall revenues of LAs, which is 
critical for their financial autonomy and sustainability. 
 
31.   The assessment rates (or Property Tax) can be increased if property valuation can be 
made more frequently and the process is simplified. Currently, valuation of property is made 
once in five years and sometimes even longer if there is a backlog in the Department of 
Valuation (DV). At present LA has to make a request to the DV at least two years ahead of time 
if the valuation is to be completed in time. In practice the LAs, do not send the request two years 
in advance and the process of valuation takes longer to complete, depriving the LA of additional 
revenue. If the valuation process is simplified, and the time frame for valuation shortened, rate 
increases could be made more frequently. Furthermore, due to poor collection efforts, many 
local authorities are unable to collect their dues. Warrant costs to be collected from defaulting 
ratepayers cannot exceed 10% of the assessment rates and therefore is dependent on the 
existing rates. If assessment rates are increased, the warrant costs would similarly increase.  
Assessment rate is allowed at maximum 12% of the assessed property value; which is in many 
LAs  currently  imposed  to  only  3-4%.  Many  mayors  said  during  appraisal  that  they  are 
considering to increase this to at last 5-6% level.     
 
32.   The local authorities have been authorized to collect an annual tax only from industries, 
trades, and businesses. Rents on buildings are authorized by the Acts, but the Council of the 
Local Authority must pass a resolution to decide on the rent to be charged, which is currently 
based on the annual value. If the estimated valuation rates are low, as is usually the case, the 
rental value may not be equal to the market value, resulting in reduced revenue. Currently, 
certain market stalls are auctioned on an annual basis to the highest bidder. In such cases, 
properties can be rented at market rates by LAs. Due to poor collection efforts by the LA, the full 
amount of the dues payable within the existing legal framework is also not usually collected. 
 
33.   There are many activities, which full cost recovery can be made. This group comprises 
of activities mainly of a service nature and includes such services as, clearing of blocked or 
overflowing  latrine  pits,  clearing  of  blocked  drains  and  drainage,  cutting  and  clearing  of 
obstructions such as trees on roads and by-lanes, garbage collection, provision of street lights, 
public toilets, visitor rest areas and markets, and regulation and control of commercial and 
business activities. In many LAs, service tax is imposed for commercial buildings and residential 
buildings which are within 100 meter radius from a specific intersection where public utility 
(communal water) is provided. By expanding the supply coverage, LAs can issue ordinance to 
increase the radius to 300m.

6.  Subprojects will be identified on the basis of needs of the local communities, financial 
and economic feasibility, environmental impact assessment, preferred government strategy, and

general criteria:

subproject should be in line with the priority requirements of the community at 
large and should address the basic urban infrastructure requirements of the LA

participatory learning and action, which allow rapid assessment of community 
needs and priorities. The proposed subproject should be in conformity with local 
master plans and vision statement (if available), and/or regional development 
plans, as well as local development goals. Subproject integration with local and 
regional plans will ensure a balanced sustainable development of the region.  
(ii)  Technical feasibility of the subproject. The subproject must be technically

to meet reasonable increases in demand. The equipment, material, and other

(iii)  Financial state of the LA. The overall financial health of the LA will be assessed

dependence on provincial/national government. Revenue-generating capacity of 
existing projects, expenditures as a proportion of expenditure norms and other 
indicators of financial strength will be used to determine capacity to repay and 
ensure sustainability of the proposed subproject. LAs that have taken loans and 
defaulted on loan and/or interest repayment will not be eligible for loans under 
the Project.

quality of proposed output will be key criteria for subproject appraisal. Quality

minimize failures but also increase life and benefits of the proposed subproject. 
(v)  Increase in revenue potential and creditworthiness for absorbing loans.

in revenue collection of the LA will be closely studied. The loan would be capped 
at 2 times the LA’s own revenues.

A.  Sector Review 
 
1.  The current urban population is about 5 million, or 27% of the population.1 Approximately 
1.5 million reside in Colombo alone. On average, the urban population is growing nearly twice 
as fast as the rural population. The degree of urbanization is projected to reach 45% by 2015.   
 
2.  Public infrastructure investment has been considerably below what is needed to sustain 
rapid growth of the economy and increasing urbanization. Generally, the level and quality of 
infrastructure  is  inadequate  and  poor.  Most  towns  experience  problems  with  congestion, 
overloaded  infrastructure  services,  intermittent  and  low-quality  water  supply,  irregular  and 
fluctuating  voltage  electrical  services,  and  substandard  roads  hampering  integration  of  the 
national economy and trade. Sanitation, drainage, and solid waste management are other 
critical problems.  
 
3.  Wide regional disparities exist in the quality and level of public infrastructure services. 
Western Province generally has better infrastructure services, notably in Colombo District and 
its environs. The incidence of poverty in urban areas (8% in 2002) is much lower than in rural 
areas (25%) (footnote 1). Per capita incomes in urban areas are more than 60% higher than the 
national average.2 These numbers provide some indication of the affordability and willingness to 
pay for infrastructure services in urban areas. However, these numbers are heavily influenced 
by Colombo district, where the medium household income is almost twice the national average. 
For the seven provinces where data are available,3 Sabaragamuwa Province is the poorest; 
North Central and Uva provinces also record per capita incomes significantly below the national 
average.

(i)  the Ministry of Provincial Councils and Local Government, with line responsibility 
for provincial and local councils; the Local Loans and Development Fund (LLDF) 
(for loans to LAs), and the Sri Lanka Institute of Local Government (for training); 
both are attached to the ministry; and 
(ii)  the  Ministry  of  Urban  Development,  Housing,  and  Construction,  with 
responsibility for providing technical support to local government in planning, 
appraisal,  procurement,  and  management;  the  Urban  Development  Authority 
(UDA)  for  designation  of  urban  areas,  planning,  and  development  (including 
capital investment plans); it is attached to the ministry.

Development  Authority,  Road  Development  Authority,  and  Ceylon  Electricity  Board  play 
important roles in providing essential infrastructure services to urban areas. Provincial councils 
and local authorities (LAs) have limited financial and personnel resources to provide urban 
infrastructure services.4 Civic amenities are their main responsibility, including operation and

16.  Implementation of urban development plans and projects require regulation of land use 
according to the provisions of the development plan, as well as power to make land available for 
infrastructure services and other development activities. Planning organizations, such as NPPD, 
have powers only to regulate land use through land use zoning and other planning controls, 
which help to carry out regulatory planning. However, urban development planning requires not 
only regulation of land use but also the promotion of required urban development activities to 
comprehensively implement an urban development plan. UDA has the regulatory power, as well 
as development promotion and land management powers, to accomplish the objectives of 
development plans. Legal provisions exist in the Land Acquisition Act (Chapter 460 of legislative 
enactments) to acquire private lands for essential public purposes. The normal acquisition 
procedure under Section 38 is a highly cumbersome and time-consuming process involving

restraining orders in many cases. Furthermore, LAs do not have the finances and capacity to 
carry out land acquisition, which at times takes well over 5 years to complete. Due to delays 
involved in normal acquisition procedures (under Section 38); a more expeditious and less time-

purposes. This requires a special certificate to be issued by the minister who initiates the 
acquisition of land required for an urgent public purpose. However, only organizations such as

concentration ratios ranging from 0.56 in Moneragala to 0.40 in Nuwara Eliya, Hambantota, and Polonnaruwa.  
 
Aside from the relatively high levels of poverty and income inequality in certain districts and provinces, the income 
structure is such that a large number of the population are near-poverty. When poverty is defined using two poverty lines, 
1996 data show that a higher poverty line of SLRs950 classifies 26% as poor; while a lower poverty line of SLRs791 
classifies 19% as poor.d This shows that although the number of core poor may not be so high, a large number of near-

This vulnerability is further aggravated by the lack of basic urban infrsstructure. A high degree of nonincome poverty 
results from the lack of basic urban infrastructure; access varies widely across provinces and districts. Using water and 
sanitation as an example, while 95.8% of the population in Colombo have access to safe drinking water, only 58.6% of the 
population in Ratnapura have access.e Similarly 97.6% of the population in Matara have latrine facilities while only 28.4% 
in Batticaloa have such facilities.  
 
A field-level analysis was conducted in 22 LAs through (i) information collection from LAs; (ii) key informant interviews in 
LAs; (iii) focus group discussions with stakeholders including subproject beneficiaries, community-based and other civic 
organizations,  and  basic  urban  service  providers;  (iv)  participatory  needs  assessment  aimed  at  identifying  basic 
infrastructure needs and priorities; (v) strengths-weaknesses-opportunities-threats analysis involving stakeholders; and (vi) 
questionnaire for potential beneficiaries. The analysis shows that poor households have very limited access to basic urban 
infrastructure. For example, the analysis shows that a third of the lowest-income households, with average monthly 
household incomes of less than SLRs1,000, have no access to safe drinking water. Of these low-income households only 
50% had access to sanitation.  
 
Participatory assessment identifies improved drinking water supply and access roads for improved economic opportunities 
as the most important needs of LAs, particularly in rural areas. Eight of 22 LAs surveyed (37%) identified water supply as 
their first priority while 18% identified access roads. The lack of access to safe drinking water required households to 
spend considerable time and effort in fetching water. This burden was especially pronounced for poor households and 
female members of these households. Public health issues arise from the use of unprotected water sources for drinking—
this increases the burden on poor households. Inadequate access roads limit the marketing of produce from poor 
communities. The lack of access roads also increases the difficulties in accessing basic urban infrastructure such as 
health centers and schools. Children in poor communities walk several kilometers to attend school. The participatory 
needs assessment also identified the need for sanitation, drainage, improved solid waste management, and improved 
institutional infrastructure.  
 
By strengthening LA capacity and providing basic urban infrastructure, an enabling environment will be created for 
delivering basic infrastructure services in a sustained manner. The Project’s LA selection criteria ensure that the Project 
will consider and prioritize LAs where poverty is high and basic infrastructure services are lacking. The Project provides 
direct benefits through increased access to basic urban infrastructure and services, and enhances the potential for 
investments and economic growth in poor areas. Key  benefits expressed by stakeholders include enabling small 
producers to market products without experiencing hardships and exploitation from agents and reduced social exclusion 
with increased transportation and mobility from access roads; increased time for productive labor for income generation; 
and improved health from improved access to drinking water. Solid waste subprojects will provide better waste disposal 
facilities to nearly half of the LA population. Water supply and sanitation subprojects are aimed at serving at least one fifth 
of the LA population currently severely constrained due to lack of access to or the poor quality of current infrastructure and 
services. The Project, through the provision of basic urban infrastructure and services, will promote human development 
envisioned to enable the poor to take advantage of potential social and economic resources and opportunities.

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
National indicators show that women in Sri Lanka have an equivalent status to men in terms of education (literacy rate for 
women is 89.2% compared with men at 92.3%; net enrolment ratio for girls is 95.6% for ages 6–10 and 97.1% for boys), 
health (life expectancy is 76.4 for women, 71.7 for men; infant mortality is 15.6 per 1,000 girls, 22.6 per 1,000 boys), and 
poverty (percentage of poor households headed by women is 21.5% compared with 23.0% for households headed by 
men). However, the labor force participation rate for women is only 33.6% compared with 67.9% for men, and female 
professional and technical workers comprise only 22.9% of total workers. 
 
Focus group discussions and field investigations show that in the project areas, women bear the primarily responsibility for 
managing the domestic environment. Their tasks include water collection and ensuring solid waste disposal. The Project 
will benefit women largely through reduced time for collecting water and other household chores related to disposing of 
solid waste. This reduces their burden from manual work, increases time for productive activities, which will raise 
household income and potentially their status in the household, and increase social and leisure time. Other externally 
supported projects (including United Nations Development Programme and United Nations-Habitat Sustainable Cities 
Program) in Sri Lanka have consistently demonstrated that women in poverty reduction programs involving water supply, 
sanitation, and microfinance have elicited women’s active participation and benefited women. Other benefits from the 
Project are likely to benefit women and men equally. Subproject design will ensure women are provided equal access to 
potential skills training and employment opportunities, and promote women’s active participation in community-based 
basic urban infrastructure provision and management.
